deliberation: I checked the imperative not to rejoice, the comparison with other nations, and especially the verbs and nouns around sexual imagery. The two clauses using זנה and אתנן clearly extend Hosea’s recurring prostitution metaphor for idolatry and materially-motivated unfaithfulness. I treat (1) the act 'you have played the harlot from your God' and (2) the love of 'a prostitute’s fee' as two related but distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: For you have strayed away (played the harlot) from your God
target: Israel’s covenant unfaithfulness toward God
Spiritual/ethical loyalty to YHWH
Covenant relationship between Israel and God
vehicle: A woman committing prostitution against her rightful partner
Sexual infidelity/prostitution
Human marital/sexual relationships
ground: Betrayal of an exclusive relationship by seeking forbidden partners
Unfaithfulness motivated by illicit desire
Moral quality of treachery and impurity
posture: Prophetic accusation portraying Israel as an unfaithful wife or harlot
Condemning, indicting stance toward Israel’s idolatry
Prophetic/theological evaluation of Israel’s behavior
instances.explanation: The verb זנה ‘to commit harlotry’ is applied to Israel’s relationship with God, metaphorically framing their religious apostasy as sexual infidelity, a conventional prophetic idiom.

instances.english_text: You have loved a prostitute’s fee on every threshing floor of grain
target: Israel’s desire for agricultural prosperity through idolatrous cults
Greedy pursuit of material benefit in religion
Socio‑religious/economic behavior of Israel
vehicle: A prostitute’s payment (אֶתְנָן) received on many threshing floors
Commercialized sexuality and its wages
Economic aspect of prostitution and cultic fees
ground: Affection directed toward material rewards gained by unfaithful conduct
A mercenary, degraded ‘love’ motivated by payment rather than covenant loyalty
Moral quality of selling oneself for profit
posture: Prophetic denunciation of Israel’s love of profit instead of love of God
Critical exposure of the sordid nature of their idolatrous ‘love’
Theological critique of prosperity‑oriented religion
instances.explanation: Israel’s delight in the agricultural yield obtained through idolatrous practices is metaphorically called a ‘prostitute’s fee’, casting their quest for fertility as selling themselves like a harlot; the threshing floors metonymically represent the whole fertility‑cult economy.

deliberation: I examined whether the agricultural images are simply literal or function symbolically. ‘Threshing floor and winepress’ stand for the entire agricultural economy (metonymy), and ‘the new wine will deceive/betray her’ personifies wine as an unreliable ally or deceiver.

instances.english_text: Threshing floor and winepress shall not feed them
target: Israel’s food supply and economic prosperity
Agricultural productivity and sustenance
Socio‑economic life of the nation
vehicle: Threshing floor and winepress installations
Places of processing grain and grapes
Agricultural infrastructure
ground: These places are the visible sources and symbols of grain and wine
Naming the key processing sites stands for the whole system of provision
Part‑for‑whole relation between facilities and total prosperity
posture: Prophetic warning that the usual sources of provision will fail
Threatening stance toward Israel’s assumed economic security
Theological interpretation of coming drought/failure as judgment
instances.explanation: ‘Threshing floor and winepress’ are concrete sites but function metonymically for all grain and wine production, summarizing Israel’s entire supply system that will no longer sustain them.

instances.english_text: And the new wine shall betray her
target: Israel’s expectation that abundant wine will secure her future
Reliance on agricultural fertility for security
National trust and hope
vehicle: A deceitful person who lies or betrays a partner
Unfaithful human ally or false friend
Interpersonal relationships marked by deception
ground: What is trusted proves unreliable and fails at a crucial moment
Apparent abundance masks ultimate failure and disappointment
Shared trait of deceptive appearance versus true outcome
posture: Prophetic undermining of Israel’s trust in material abundance
Critical stance exposing the ‘treachery’ of what they rely on
Theological insistence that only God, not produce, is trustworthy
instances.explanation: Wine, an inanimate product, is personified and metaphorically depicted as a traitor who deceives Israel, highlighting that their trusted prosperity will let them down.

deliberation: I checked whether the phrases are purely geographic or symbolic. ‘Land of YHWH’ is a theological designation but not clearly figurative. However, ‘Ephraim shall return to Egypt’ in Hosea is a stereotyped way of speaking about going back into bondage/exile, with Egypt standing for oppressive foreign rule rather than a simple travel notice.

instances.english_text: But Ephraim shall return to Egypt
target: Israel’s impending exile and renewed experience of foreign bondage
National judgment in the form of subjugation by foreign powers
Historical-political fate of the northern kingdom
vehicle: Egypt, the place of Israel’s former slavery
Archetypal land of oppression and bondage
Geopolitical entity with a symbolic history
ground: Egypt is remembered as the paradigmatic place of forced servitude
Going ‘back to Egypt’ evokes the idea of reversing the exodus salvation
Shared notion of being under harsh foreign domination
posture: Prophetic portrayal of exile as a tragic reversal of redemption
Warning that covenant breach undoes the exodus gift
Theological reading of future history through the lens of past bondage
instances.explanation: ‘Return to Egypt’ functions as an idiomatic metonymy: Egypt stands for any oppressive exile that undoes Israel’s redeemed status, not merely for literal resettlement there.

deliberation: I considered whether ‘food of mourners’ is a metaphor; in context it refers to ritually defiled food after contact with the dead, a technical cultic category, so I treated it as literal. The primary figurative feature here is the conventional phrase ‘House of YHWH’, which uses ‘house’ metonymically for God’s temple/worship presence.

instances.english_text: the House of the LORD
target: The temple/worship center and presence of YHWH
Official cult and meeting place between God and Israel
Religious-institutional sphere
vehicle: A house or dwelling place
Physical building as a locus of a person’s presence and authority
Domestic/architectural domain
ground: A house is where a person resides and receives guests
Calling the temple ‘God’s house’ presents it as His dwelling among His people
Part‑for‑whole relation between a building and the activities/authority centered there
posture: Covenantal depiction of Israel as admitted (or barred) guests in God’s dwelling
Emphasizes intimacy but also the right of the owner to exclude
Theological framing of cultic access as hospitality from God
instances.explanation: ‘House of YHWH’ is not a private residence but a metonymic way to speak of the temple and God’s cultic presence, conceptualizing God as a householder who can accept or refuse Israel.

deliberation: I checked for metaphors in ‘day of appointed time’ and ‘day of the festival of YHWH’; here they appear as literal cultic calendar designations, with only a rhetorical question but no figurative imagery or personification.

I evaluated ‘Egypt will gather them, Moph will bury them’ for personification and metonymy, and the clauses about weeds and thorns for metaphor. Egypt/Memphis function as place‑for‑people metonymies and quasi‑personified agents of exile and death. The imagery of weeds inheriting silver and thorns in tents is an extended metaphor/personification for desolation.

instances.english_text: Egypt shall gather them, Moph shall bury them
target: The fate of Israel’s people in exile (capture and death)
National judgment through deportation and mortality abroad
Historical-political destiny of the northern kingdom
vehicle: Egypt and Moph (Memphis) acting as gatherer and undertaker
Foreign land and capital city personified as active agents
Geographical-political entities
ground: Egypt/Memphis stand for their regimes and peoples who will control Israel’s fate
The lands where exiles are taken become the ‘gatherers’ and buriers of the defeated
Use of place names to evoke oppressive powers and their actions
posture: Prophetic portrayal of foreign nations as instruments of divine judgment
Sobering depiction of exile as being swallowed up by another land
Theological emphasis on total loss of autonomy, even in burial
instances.explanation: Egypt and Memphis are metonymically and personifiedly depicted as agents who ‘gather’ and ‘bury’ Israel, summarizing the entire experience of captivity and dying on foreign soil.

instances.hebrew_text: מַחְמַד לְכַסְפָּם קִמּוֹשׂ יִירָשֵׁם חוֹחַ בְּאׇהֳלֵיהֶם
instances.english_text: As for their precious silver, weeds shall inherit it; prickly shrubs [will be] in their tents
target: The loss of Israel’s wealth and homes through judgment and abandonment
Desolation of property and homesteads
Socio‑economic consequences of national ruin
vehicle: Weeds inheriting silver and thorns occupying tents
Wild plants behaving like heirs and new occupants
Natural overgrowth in abandoned places
ground: In abandoned places, nature overruns former wealth and dwellings
Weeds ‘taking over’ parallels heirs taking possession of an estate
Shared idea of previous owners’ disappearance and replacement
posture: Vividly picturing judgment as nature reclaiming what was once Israel’s
Mournful yet accusatory tone about the futility of their treasures
Prophetic insistence that what they prized will pass to non‑human ‘heirs’
instances.explanation: Weeds and thorns are personified as heirs and occupants of Israel’s valuables and tents, a metaphor for the complete desolation and abandonment of their wealth and homes.

deliberation: I checked whether ‘days of punishment’ and ‘days of recompense’ are metaphorical time expressions; they are abstract but not strongly figurative. The clause ‘the prophet is a fool, the man of the spirit is mad’ functions as an ironic reversal: the true prophet is derided as insane because of the people’s sin, a use of irony rather than metaphor.

instances.english_text: The prophet is a fool, the man of the spirit is mad
target: The true status and role of God’s prophet in Israel
Perception of prophetic ministry
Religious leadership and revelation
vehicle: A ‘fool’ and a ‘madman’ as labels of contempt
Socially derided irrational person
Psychological/social deviance
ground: From the people’s corrupt perspective, the prophet’s message seems insane
There is a contrast between appearance (madness) and reality (divine inspiration)
Irony arises from misjudging God’s spokesman
posture: Ironic and polemical stance: echoing the people’s insult to expose their guilt
Highlights the inversion of values in a sinful society
Prophetic defense of the true, though despised, messenger
instances.explanation: The line is ironic: those who ought to honor God’s ‘man of the spirit’ instead brand him a fool and madman, revealing their own deep corruption; the rhetorical force rests on this inversion, not on literal description.

deliberation: The verse is textually difficult, but in any reading the prophet is likened to a watchman, and then to a snare. These are two distinct metaphors: (1) the positive role of prophet as a lookout, and (2) the corrupt prophet (or people's view of him) as a bird‑trap ensnaring others.

instances.english_text: A watchman is over Ephraim with my God—the prophet
target: The prophetic office watching over Ephraim
Spiritual oversight and warning function
Religious leadership role
vehicle: A city watchman stationed on the walls
Guardian who scans the horizon for danger
Military/urban security practice
ground: Both prophet and watchman are responsible to detect danger early
They must warn the community of approaching threats
Shared role of vigilance and protective oversight
posture: Affirming the ideal function of the prophet as God’s lookout
Shows divine alignment (‘with my God’) of true prophetic watching
Sets a standard against which corrupt practice is judged
instances.explanation: The prophet is metaphorically called a ‘watchman’ over Ephraim, picturing his task as guarding the people by warning of coming judgment, just as a sentry guards a city.

instances.english_text: The prophet is a fowler’s snare on all his paths
target: The corrupt influence of the (false or compromised) prophet on Israel
Misleading spiritual guidance
Social-religious danger posed by leadership
vehicle: A bird‑trap or snare spread along paths
Hidden device that captures unsuspecting victims
Hunting technology
ground: Both ensnare and bring ruin to those who pass by trustingly
They operate deceptively, often unseen until it is too late
Shared trait of being a source of entrapment rather than safety
posture: Harshly critical portrayal of the prophet’s effect on the people
Warns that listening to such a prophet is spiritually deadly
Turns the ‘watchman’ image inside‑out into a trap
instances.explanation: Here the prophet is not a guardian but likened to a bird‑snare, suggesting that instead of protecting the people he lures and traps them into destruction.

deliberation: I considered the historical comparison ‘as in the days of Gibeah’ (an allusion rather than a simile) and the phrase ‘they have deepened their corruption’. The verb ‘deepened’ applies spatial imagery of depth to moral ruin, a moral‑spatial metaphor common in Hebrew.

instances.english_text: They have deeply corrupted themselves
target: The extent of Israel’s moral and spiritual corruption
Degree of wickedness and depravity
Ethical-spiritual condition of the people
vehicle: Going down to a deep place
Physical depth and descent
Spatial dimension (vertical depth)
ground: Both ‘going deep’ and becoming extremely corrupt go beyond the surface or ordinary level
Imagery of depth conveys intensity and entrenchment
Shared notion of being far removed from the proper/normal state
posture: Emphasizes the seriousness and entrenched nature of their sin
Intensifies the accusation through spatial metaphor
Warns that their state is not superficial but profoundly rooted
instances.explanation: The verb ‘they have deepened’ uses vertical depth metaphorically for the intensity of their self‑ruin, picturing their sin as plunging ever further down.

deliberation: I noted three explicit כּ‑comparisons: Israel as grapes in the wilderness, the ancestors as first‑ripe figs, and Israel becoming detestable ‘like’ what they loved. These are three distinct similes; the references to ‘shame’ and ‘abominations’ for Baal are contemptuous labels but function more as pejorative renamings than separate metaphors here.

instances.english_text: I found Israel [as pleasing] as grapes in the wilderness
target: God’s initial delight in Israel
Perceived value and freshness of Israel at first
Covenant affection at the outset
vehicle: Grapes found in the wilderness
Unexpected, refreshing fruit in a barren place
Agricultural produce in a harsh environment
ground: Both are rare, surprising, and highly prized in their setting
They bring joy and satisfaction when unexpectedly encountered
Shared sense of preciousness against a background of barrenness
posture: Affectionate recollection of how God once regarded Israel
Highlights the contrast with their later apostasy
Sets a tone of disappointed love
instances.explanation: God compares His discovery of Israel to finding grapes in a desert, a simile expressing how unexpectedly delightful and precious they once appeared.

instances.english_text: Your ancestors seemed to Me like the first fig to ripen on a fig tree
target: God’s favorable view of Israel’s forefathers
Initial promise and attractiveness of the ancestors
Early stage of the covenant relationship
vehicle: The first ripe fig at the beginning of the fig season
Earliest, choicest fruit
Agricultural firstfruits
ground: First ripe figs are eagerly anticipated and especially valued
Both carry a sense of early, promising yield
Shared association of delight and special status
posture: Reminiscent praise of the ancestors as once‑precious to God
Sets up a tragic contrast with later generations’ idolatry
Frames the story as decline from early promise
instances.explanation: The ancestors are compared to the first ripe fig, a simile expressing their special, eagerly awaited value at the beginning of Israel’s history.

instances.english_text: Then they became as detestable as what they loved
target: Israel’s moral/spiritual transformation through idolatry
Character of the people shaped by their worship
Ethical-spiritual likeness to idols
vehicle: The detestable object(s) they loved (Baal/‘shame’)
Abominable idol or shameful cult
Religious object of devotion
ground: Lovers come to resemble what they adore in values and character
Idols and shameful cults are ‘detestable’; Israel imitates that quality
Shared trait of repulsiveness before God
posture: Condemns Israel by equating them morally with their idols
Warns that worship shapes identity, for ill here
Theological explanation of corruption as becoming like one’s god
instances.explanation: Using a simile, Hosea says Israel became ‘as detestable as what they loved’, asserting that by loving shameful idols they took on the abominable character of their gods.

deliberation: The key figurative element is the comparison of Ephraim’s ‘glory’ to a bird that flies away, an explicit simile capturing the swift, irretrievable loss of honor and offspring. The birth‑terms themselves are literal.

instances.english_text: Ephraim—like a bird, their glory shall fly away
target: Ephraim’s glory, including children and status
Honor, vitality, and continuation of the nation
Social-familial flourishing
vehicle: A bird that flies away
Small, mobile creature quickly disappearing from sight
Natural image of swift departure
ground: Both can vanish suddenly and be hard or impossible to retrieve
Movement is rapid and in one direction away from the observer
Shared impression of transience and loss
posture: Laments but also warns of the fragility of Ephraim’s glory
Presents the loss of offspring and honor as swift and final
Underscores the seriousness of judgment on fertility
instances.explanation: Ephraim’s ‘glory’—likely their children and status—is compared to a bird flying away, a simile picturing its rapid, irretrievable loss.

deliberation: Most of the verse is straightforward threat language. I considered whether ‘when I turn away from them’ is just spatial description or a relational metaphor; in Hebrew ‘turning away’ from someone commonly figures relational rejection, so I treat that as a metaphor for withdrawing favor.

instances.english_text: when I turn away from them
target: God’s decision to withdraw His favor and presence from Israel
Relational rejection and abandonment
Divine‑human covenant relationship
vehicle: Physically turning one’s body away from someone
Breaking face‑to‑face contact and moving aside
Spatial orientation in human interaction
ground: Turning away physically symbolizes ending engagement and concern
Both involve cessation of attentive, supportive presence
Shared implication of rejection and distance
posture: Expresses divine judgment as the withdrawal of relational nearness
Highlights the personal dimension of Israel’s loss (not just events)
Warns that their behavior leads to being forsaken
instances.explanation: God’s ‘turning away’ uses bodily orientation as a metaphor for relational rejection—He will no longer face or attend to Israel, signifying abandonment.

deliberation: I focused on the comparison with Tyre and the planting imagery. Tyre ‘planted in a meadow’ itself is a metaphor (city as a well‑planted entity), and Ephraim is said to fare ‘as’ Tyre did. I treat this as one plant‑based simile describing Ephraim’s formerly secure, pleasant situation.

instances.english_text: Ephraim—as I have seen it go with Tyre, which was planted in a meadow
target: Ephraim’s former position of security and pleasant prosperity
National stability and flourishing before judgment
Political-economic condition of the kingdom
vehicle: Tyre as a plant ‘planted in a meadow’
Well‑rooted vegetation in a fertile, pleasant place
Agricultural image of secure growth
ground: Both a well‑planted tree and a secure city/enjoying nation are firmly established and well‑situated
They draw continuous sustenance from a favorable environment
Shared image of flourishing in a good location
posture: Recalls how promising and secure Ephraim once appeared, like Tyre
Sets the stage for the shock of bringing children out to the slayer
Uses flourishing‑plant imagery to heighten the tragedy of coming ruin
instances.explanation: Ephraim’s secure state is likened to Tyre pictured as a plant ‘planted in a meadow’; this simile/metaphor casts the nation’s former prosperity as that of a well‑rooted plant in a pleasant place.

deliberation: I examined whether ‘a womb that miscarries and shriveled breasts’ are symbolic or literal. They function primarily as concrete imprecations for barrenness and infant death, without an additional figurative mapping beyond the direct curse itself. I therefore do not mark a distinct figurative expression.

I checked ‘all their evil is in Gilgal’ (which situationally highlights that place but is not in itself figurative) and focused on ‘from my house I will drive them out’. This uses ‘house’ for God’s temple/presence (metonymy) and casts the covenant relationship as a household where God expels unwanted members, giving a metaphor of familial/household rejection.

instances.english_text: From My house I will drive them out
target: Israel’s exclusion from God’s presence and covenant fellowship
Loss of cultic access and belonging to God’s people
Divine-human relational standing
vehicle: A householder expelling people from his own house
Domestic scene of driving out unwelcome or disowned occupants
Family/household life
ground: Both involve removing people from a place of intimacy and provision
Being ‘driven out’ of a house signifies rejection and loss of status as family or guests
Shared sense of severed relationship and loss of protection
posture: Presents judgment as God’s decisive act of disowning and expelling
Stresses the personal, relational dimension of Israel’s rejection
Warns that their sin forfeits the privilege of dwelling in God’s ‘house’
instances.explanation: God’s ‘house’ is the temple/presence of YHWH, and expelling Israel from it is metaphorically described as a householder driving people out of his home, conveying familial rejection.

deliberation: I examined whether the language of striking, root, and fruit is literal or figurative. ‘Ephraim is stricken’ is idiomatic judgment language; the main explicit metaphor is the plant imagery: Ephraim’s root is dried up, and they can bear no fruit, depicting the nation as a plant whose life‑source has withered.

instances.hebrew_text: הֻכָּה אֶפְרַיִם שָׁרְשָׁם יָבֵשׁ פְּרִי בַל־יַעֲשׂוּן
instances.english_text: Ephraim is stricken; their root is dried up, they can produce no fruit
target: The life, strength, and generative capacity of the nation Ephraim
National vitality, stability, and ability to produce offspring or success
Corporate existence of Israel
vehicle: A plant with a dried‑up root that bears no fruit
Botanical life dependent on roots and fruit‑bearing
Agricultural growth cycle
ground: Both a withered plant and a judged nation lack inner vitality and outward productivity
Dry root signifies no source of nourishment; no fruit signifies no outcome or continuation
Shared sense of inevitable decline and death
posture: Depicts judgment as cutting off Ephraim’s life‑source and future
Uses familiar agricultural imagery to make national ruin vivid
Warns that their current prosperity will not continue
instances.explanation: Ephraim is metaphorically presented as a plant whose root has dried up and thus cannot bear fruit, signifying the loss of inner vitality and the end of productive future (including offspring).

deliberation: I considered whether ‘My God will reject them’ and ‘they shall be wanderers among the nations’ are metaphorical. ‘Reject’ uses relational language, and ‘wanderers’ can be literal for exiles scattered among nations. There is no clear additional figurative vehicle beyond the straightforward description of rejection and dispersion.
